questions.text: Activity 1: Sanding timber – what is the appropriate respiratory protection?
questions.hint: Think: dust in the air (particulate).

rubric.check: ^Dust mask / particulate respirator for sanding timber$

options: Dust mask / particulate respirator for sanding timber
Respirator with appropriate filters for spraying glue
Air-fed breathing apparatus for two-pot paint

questions.text: Activity 2: Arc welding – what is the appropriate respiratory protection?
questions.hint: Think: fumes/smoke created by the process (not just dust).
options: Dust mask / particulate respirator for sanding timber
Respirator with appropriate filters for spraying glue
Air-fed breathing apparatus for two-pot paint

questions.text: Activity 3: Spraying glue – what is the appropriate respiratory protection?
questions.hint: Think: chemical vapours/aerosols (filters matter).

rubric.check: ^Respirator with appropriate filters for spraying glue$

options: Dust mask / particulate respirator for sanding timber
Respirator with appropriate filters for spraying glue
Air-fed breathing apparatus for two-pot paint

questions.text: Activity 4: Spraying ‘two-pot’ paint – what is the appropriate respiratory protection?
questions.hint: Think: the highest-risk spray process in the list (needs its own clean air supply).
options: Dust mask / particulate respirator for sanding timber
Respirator with appropriate filters for spraying glue
Air-fed breathing apparatus for two-pot paint

ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-reflection 2 – 24352 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: US 24352 – Safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text:
Compile a list of rules/codes of conduct that would ensure safe working practices in a BCATS environment.

Example: Wear appropriate eye protection at all times.
questions.hint: Cover behaviour, PPE, clothing/hair, housekeeping, supervision, and reporting hazards.

questions.text: For each rule listed in Question 1 (a–h), describe a possible consequence if that rule is not followed.
questions.hint: Link each rule to a realistic injury/accident (eyes, lungs, hearing, entanglement, trips/falls, strains).

questions.text: Q2: Why should jandals never be worn on a work site?
questions.hint: Think about toe protection, grip, and what happens if something sharp/heavy lands on your foot.

questions.text: Q3: Identify the hazard – What type of clothing would be a hazard to wear around heat or sparks?
questions.hint: Think about fabrics that melt or catch easily, and clothing that leaves skin exposed.

questions.text: Q3: Identify the hazard – What type of clothing would be a hazard to wear around machinery such as lathes?
questions.hint: Think about anything that can get caught in moving parts.

questions.text: Q3: Identify the hazard – What type of clothing would be a hazard to wear when spraying paint?
questions.hint: Think about overspray/chemicals contacting skin and clothing that doesn’t cover your body.

questions.text: Q4: Identify the potential hazards of wearing long hair around machinery.
questions.hint: What can moving parts do if they grab hair?

questions.text: Q5a: Identify the purpose of the signage (warning to keep clear of moving machinery).
questions.hint: What action is it telling you to take, and what injury is it trying to prevent?

questions.text: Q5b: Identify the purpose of the signage (warning about dust inhalation / wearing a mask).
questions.hint: Think about lungs and airborne particles.

questions.text: Q6: When nailing timber you should always wear eye protection. Describe an eye hazard associated with this activity.
questions.hint: Think about what can fly upward unexpectedly.

questions.text: Q7: Describe the general risks of not maintaining PPE (cleaning, checking damage, correct storage).
questions.hint: Think: reduced protection and new problems created by dirty/damaged PPE.

questions.text: Q7: Describe a risk of not maintaining safety glasses.
questions.hint: Think: seeing clearly and hygiene.

questions.text: Q7: Describe a risk of not maintaining respiratory protection (mask/respirator).
questions.hint: Think: filters, sealing, and long-term health effects.

questions.text: Q7: Describe a risk of not maintaining ear muffs/hearing protection.
questions.hint: Think: sealing around the ear and what noise does over time.

questions.text: Q7: Describe a risk of not maintaining a hard hat.
questions.hint: Think: cracks and impact protection.

questions.text: Q7: Describe a risk of not maintaining gloves.
questions.hint: Think: holes/tears and what hands contact in a workshop.

questions.text:
Q8(a): You are using an electric router to shape the edges of a rimu table top.
Identify at least FOUR hazards and the PPE that will help.
questions.hint: Consider hazards to eyes, lungs, hearing, body/clothing, hands and feet.

questions.text:
Q8(b): You are breaking up a concrete path using a sledge hammer.
Identify at least THREE hazards and the PPE that will help.
questions.hint: Think: flying debris, dust, impact noise, hands, and feet.

questions.text:
Q8(c): You are turning a bowl on a wood lathe.
Identify at least THREE hazards and the PPE that will help.
questions.hint: Think: high-speed chips, dust, hearing, hair/clothing.

questions.text:
Q8(d): You are unloading sheets of plywood off a truck and stacking them in a storage shed.
Identify at least THREE hazards and the PPE that will help.
questions.hint: Think: manual handling, sharp edges/splinters, and feet if sheets drop.
